Key Match Events: An inning that started with a Gerrit Cole no-hitter watch and turned into an almost incomprehensible five-run inning for the team he was no-hitting.
Five runs were unearned in the fifth inning due to three errors, a balk, and a catcher's interference.
Jack Flaherty got four outs, while Blake Treinen arrived in the sixth inning and pitched 42 pitches.
Walker Buehler, with no prior saves in his career, closed out the game to win the World Series.
Pre-Game Insights: Andrew Friedman, president of baseball operations for the Dodgers, emphasized the unpredictability of baseball.
Dodgers were aware of the possibility of blowing a five-run lead but focused on the long game.
Post-Match Reflections: Mookie Betts highlighted the resilience of the team throughout the season, saying the game epitomized their journey.
Andrew Friedman praised the beauty of baseball and the unpredictable nature of the sport.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was the first in which a team blew a five-run lead and lost in a World Series game since 1956.
Walker Buehler's save was the first of his big-league career in a World Series clincher.
The game featured the first instance of a team taking the lead for good in a World Series inning with unearned runs.
